name: Terraform
description: Execute terraform commands to manage resources on AzureRM, Amazon Web Services(AWS) and Google Cloud Platform(GCP)
author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: backend
inputs.label: Backend
inputs.helpMarkDown: The selected backend type where state will managed from.

inputs.name: provider
inputs.label: Provider
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The name of the provider used in the terraform configuration files.
Only one provider must be specified in the terraform configuration files in the below specified configuration directory.

inputs.name: workingDirectory
inputs.label: Configuration directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Directory containing the Terraform configuration files. The default value is $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)

inputs.name: commandOptions
inputs.label: Additional command arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Any additional arguments for the selected command such as '-option=value' or '-flag'. Multiple options can also be provided delimited by spaces.

Examples:
-out=tfplan (for terraform plan)
tfplan -auto-approve (for terraform apply)

inputs.name: environmentServiceNameAzureRM
inputs.label: Provider Connection
inputs.visibleRule: provider = azurerm && command != init && command != validate
inputs.helpMarkDown: Azure subscription connection to deploy with.

inputs.name: environmentServiceNameAWS
inputs.label: Provider Connection
inputs.visibleRule: provider = aws && command != init && command != validate
inputs.helpMarkDown:
AWS connection to deploy with.

Note: If your connection is not listed or if you want to use an existing connection, you can setup an Amazon Web Services service connection using the 'Add' or 'Manage' button.

inputs.name: environmentServiceNameGCP
inputs.label: Provider Connection
inputs.visibleRule: provider = gcp && command != init && command != validate
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Google Cloud connection to deploy with.

Note: If your connection is not listed or if you want to use an existing connection, you can setup a Google Cloud Platform service connection using the 'Add' or 'Manage' button.

inputs.name: backendServiceAzureRM
inputs.label: Connection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Azure resource manager subscription for the terraform backend configuration

inputs.name: backendAzureRMResourceGroupName
inputs.label: Resource Group
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the resource group which contains the storage account selected below.

inputs.name: backendAzureRMStorageAccountName
inputs.label: Storage Account
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the storage account which contains the Azure Blob container selected below.

inputs.name: backendAzureRMContainerName
inputs.label: Blob Container
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the Azure Blob container in which to store the Terraform remote state file.

inputs.name: backendAzureRMKey
inputs.label: File Path
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The path to the Terraform remote state file inside the container.
For example, if you want to store the state file, named terraform.tfstate, inside a folder, named tf, then give the input 'tf/terraform.tfstate'

inputs.name: backendServiceS3
inputs.label: Connection
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Amazon Web Services connection for the terraform backend configuration.

Note: If your connection is not listed or if you want to use an existing connection, you can setup an Amazon Web Services service connection using the 'Add' or 'Manage' button.

inputs.name: backendS3BucketName
inputs.label: S3 Bucket
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The name of the Amazon Simple Storage Service (S3) bucket for storing the Terraform remote state file.

NOTE: The region of this bucket (e.g. us-east-1) must be specified in the AWS service connection that you must set up. To set up an AWS service connection, click on the 'Help(i)' button of the above input named 'Amazon Web Services connection'

inputs.name: backendS3Key
inputs.label: File Path
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The path to the state file inside the Amazon S3 bucket.
For example, if you want to store the state file, named terraform.tfstate, inside a folder, named tf, then give the input 'tf/terraform.tfstate'.

inputs.name: backendServiceGCS
inputs.label: Connection
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Google Cloud Platform connection for the terraform backend configuration.

Note: If your connection is not listed or if you want to use an existing connection, you can setup a Google Cloud Platform service connection using the 'Add' or 'Manage' button.

inputs.name: backendGCSBucketName
inputs.label: Storage Bucket
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the GCP storage bucket for storing the Terraform remote state file.

inputs.name: backendGCSPrefix
inputs.label: Path
inputs.helpMarkDown: The relative path to the state file inside the GCP bucket. For example, if you give the input as 'terraform', then the state file, named default.tfstate, will be stored inside an object called terraform.

OutputVariables.name: jsonPlanFilePath
OutputVariables.description:
The location of the terraform plan file in JSON format that was created. This file can be used by tasks which are written for tools such as [Open Policy Agent](https://www.openpolicyagent.org/docs/latest/terraform/)

Note: This variable will only be set if 'command' input is set to 'plan'.

OutputVariables.name: jsonOutputVariablesPath
OutputVariables.description:
The location of the JSON file which contains the output variables set by the user in the terraform config files.

Note: This variable will only be set if 'command' input is set to 'apply'.
